summary: John R. Tunheim was a member of the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB). The documents reflect his involvement in overseeing the declassification and release of JFK assassination records. He played a role in requesting additional information from the CIA, addressing concerns about the pace of declassification, and making formal determinations regarding the public disclosure of CIA records related to the assassination. His work involved interacting with the CIA's Historical Review Group (HRG) and Director of Central Intelligence George Tenet. Tunheim's involvement spans from at least 1994 to 1998, as indicated by the dates of the documents. He was involved in ensuring compliance with the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992.
significance: John R. Tunheim's significance lies in his role as a member of the ARRB, which was responsible for overseeing the declassification and release of government records related to the JFK assassination. He was directly involved in requesting information from the CIA, addressing concerns about the pace of declassification, and making formal determinations regarding the public disclosure of CIA records. His work was crucial in ensuring compliance with the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act of 1992 and promoting transparency regarding the events surrounding the assassination.
